document_title: Age-related alterations in the sarcolemmal environment are attenuated by lifelong caloric restriction and voluntary exercise
summary_full: This study investigated the effects of lifelong mild caloric restriction (CR) and CR combined with voluntary wheel running (WR) on age-related changes in the sarcolemmal environment of rat plantaris muscle fibers. Aging led to discontinuous expression of dystrophin glycoprotein complex (DGC) proteins (dystrophin, α-syntrophin, nNOS) and increased membrane repair proteins (MG53, dysferlin, annexins A6 and A2). Conversely, aged muscle showed reduced levels of NADPH oxidase isoform 2 (Nox2) subunits. Lifelong CR and CR+WR interventions significantly protected against DGC disruption and maintained membrane repair proteins near young adult levels. These interventions also prevented the age-related decline in Nox2 subunits. The findings suggest that lifelong CR and WR are effective countermeasures against age-related sarcolemmal alterations, potentially mitigating sarcopenia and improving muscle health.
key_findings: Lifelong mild caloric restriction (8%) and combined caloric restriction with voluntary wheel running attenuated age-related loss of muscle fiber cross-sectional area.
These interventions prevented the age-related discontinuity and dissociation of sarcolemmal dystrophin, α-syntrophin, and nNOS.
Lifelong CR and CR+WR maintained membrane repair proteins (MG53, dysferlin, annexin A6, annexin A2) at levels similar to young adults, counteracting age-induced increases.
The age-related reduction in key NADPH oxidase isoform 2 (Nox2) subunits (p67phox, p47phox) was prevented by lifelong CR and CR+WR.
These interventions preserved a healthier sarcolemmal environment, potentially contributing to the mitigation of sarcopenia.
future_research_fields: Investigating the specific roles of Nox2 subunits and mitochondrial ROS in age-related muscle decline.
Exploring sex-related differences in the response to caloric restriction and exercise in aging muscle.
Determining the precise mechanisms by which CR and WR protect sarcolemmal integrity.
Evaluating the long-term functional consequences of these interventions on muscle strength and mobility in aged individuals.
Assessing the impact of CR and WR on other muscle types and their specific age-related vulnerabilities.

conclusions: Lifelong mild caloric restriction and voluntary wheel running are effective countermeasures against age-related alterations in the myofiber membrane environment, including DGC disruption, increased membrane repair protein abundance, and reduced Nox2 subunit levels. These interventions help maintain sarcolemmal integrity and may prevent age-related muscle mass and function decline (sarcopenia).
impact_statement: This study demonstrates that lifelong caloric restriction and exercise can preserve skeletal muscle sarcolemmal health during aging, offering potential strategies to combat sarcopenia and improve quality of life in older populations.
